This directory contains French-language 'how-to' guides specifically related to data migration within the user documentation for the 'twenty' package. It provides practical, step-by-step instructions for users performing data migration tasks.

This directory contains French-localized documentation detailing the capabilities related to data migration within the 'twenty' project's user guide. It outlines the specific features and functionalities available for data migration.

This directory contains Italian localized documentation detailing the specific capabilities and features related to data migration within the user guide for the 'twenty' project. It serves as a section within the broader data migration documentation, outlining what can be achieved.

This directory contains 'how-to' guides for users on data migration within the Twenty project. It provides practical, step-by-step instructions specifically for the Italian localized version of the user documentation.

This directory contains 'how-to' guides for data migration within the user guide documentation for the 'twenty' project. It provides practical, step-by-step instructions for users on various data migration tasks, likely localized for a specific language (e.g., Czech).

This directory is intended to define and document the specific capabilities and features related to data migration within the 'twenty' project. It serves as a focused section within the user guide, likely providing detailed information on what users can achieve during data migration.
This directory contains 'how-to' guides specifically detailing data migration procedures. It serves as a practical resource within the user guide for tasks related to migrating data.

This directory is part of the `twenty` project's user guide, specifically detailing the features and functionalities available for data migration. It outlines the specific capabilities offered for users performing data transfers or upgrades.

This directory contains 'how-to' guides for data migration, specifically tailored for the Turkish localization of the user guide within the 'twenty-docs' package. It provides step-by-step instructions for common data migration tasks relevant to Turkish-speaking users.

This directory is intended to house documentation or resources that describe the specific capabilities and features of data migration within the 'twenty' project's user guide. It is part of the Turkish localization of the project's documentation package.
This directory contains practical 'how-to' guides for data migration. These guides are part of the Romanian user documentation for the 'twenty' project, offering step-by-step instructions for users.

This directory provides documentation within the 'twenty' project's user guide, specifically outlining the capabilities and features available for data migration. It details what users can expect and achieve when performing data migration tasks.

AI Assistant.description: Offers AI-powered features such as an interactive chat assistant to help users find information, execute tasks, and gain insights from their data. It integrates with various AI models and system tools.

files.description: This file defines the `SlashCommandRenderer` class, which is responsible for dynamically creating, rendering, updating, and destroying a React `SlashCommandMenu` component outside the main React DOM tree, typically used for overlay or popup UIs in an advanced text editor.

This component implements the UI and interaction logic for a customizable slash command menu within a rich text editor. It provides a dropdown list of commands, keyboard navigation, and handles command selection.
This hook provides a collection of record-agnostic actions, dynamically including AI-related actions based on whether the AI feature flag is enabled.

This file defines an enumeration of keys for actions that are not specific to a particular record, used within an action menu. It lists various general actions like searching records or interacting with AI.

This file defines the configuration for a set of record-agnostic global actions, such as searching records, asking AI, and viewing previous AI chats. Each action specifies its type, scope, labels, icon, hotkeys, and the side panel component it opens within the command menu.

This file defines a custom React hook that facilitates the creation of new AI chat threads, updates the current chat thread state upon successful creation, and opens the AI chat interface in the command menu.

This file defines a React hook that provides a function to programmatically open and navigate to the 'Ask AI' page within the application's command menu. It allows customization of the page title and control over resetting the command menu's navigation stack.
This hook updates the title and icon for the current page in a command menu, ensuring both the page information state and the navigation stack reflect the changes.

This file defines a React hook `useCopyContextStoreStates` that facilitates copying multiple Recoil context store states from one component instance to another. It allows synchronizing various UI-related states like filters, selections, view IDs, and edit modes between different instances within the application.
Tests the `useCommandMenuHistory` hook, which manages the command menu's navigation stack by simulating navigation, going back, and navigating to specific points in the history.

This file contains unit tests for the `useFilterActionsWithCommandMenuSearch` hook. It verifies that the hook correctly filters action configurations based on a search string, matching against action labels and hotkeys.
This file contains unit tests for the `useNavigateCommandMenu` hook, verifying its functionality in updating the command menu's navigation state, including the current page and navigation stack.

This file defines the `CommandMenuForMobile` component, which renders the command menu in a full-screen, mobile-optimized format when it is active. It uses `createPortal` to attach the menu to the document body and Recoil for state management.
This React component manages the focus state of a command menu input. It ensures the input element automatically gains focus when the command menu is on its root or search records page.

This React component displays a chip in a command menu, summarizing a selection of records from a specific context by showing their count and associated avatars. It integrates metadata and context-selected record data to render this summary.

This component serves as a container for the command menu, setting up essential context providers (for action menus, context store, and AI agent chat) and managing relevant metadata based on the current view and selected object.

This file defines the CommandMenuTopBar component, which serves as the interactive search bar and navigation header for the command menu, managing search input, displaying navigation controls, and showing current context information.

This file defines a `CommandMenuItemNumberInput` component, which provides a number input field within a command menu item. It handles input validation, focus management, and user interaction events like committing changes on enter/blur or escaping changes.

This component renders a dynamic icon in the command menu's top right corner. It provides navigation to AI features (if enabled) or a back button within the command menu, depending on the current state.

This file defines a `CommandMenuItemTextInput` component, which renders a text input field within a command menu item, allowing users to modify a value with integrated focus management and event handling (e.g., on enter, escape, or click outside).

This file defines the `CommandMenuOpenContainer` React component, which serves as the animated container for the command menu. It handles the styling, animation (opening/closing), and outside click detection to close the menu, adapting its behavior for mobile and desktop views.

This directory is designated to contain custom React hooks specifically for components within the `command-menu` module. These hooks would encapsulate reusable logic and stateful behavior, promoting reusability and separation of concerns for the command menu's UI.
This file defines the type for an item in the command menu's navigation stack and exports a state management object to track the current navigation stack for the command menu.
This file defines and exports a global state object for managing information about the current page within a command menu, including its title, an optional icon, and an instance identifier.

This file defines a component instance context specifically for the Command Menu Page Component. It uses a utility to create a context that can manage instance-specific state, initialized with an empty instance ID.
This file defines a GraphQL query (`SEARCH_QUERY`) used by the command menu to perform a search operation across various objects, supporting filtering and pagination.
This file defines a React page component that displays a list of AI chat threads within the application's command menu. It acts as a container for the `AIChatThreadsList` component.
This file defines the `CommandMenuAskAIPage` component, which serves as a page for an AI chat interface accessible via a command menu. It primarily renders the `AIChatTab` component.
This component renders a page displaying search records for the command menu, fetching data using a custom hook and presenting it via a CommandMenuList.

This file defines a component state that stores the ID of the currently viewable front-end component within the command menu. It allows tracking which front component is being displayed or managed by the command menu.

This file defines a component-level state, `messageThreadComponentState`, used to manage a `MessageThread` object for the command menu's message thread page. It is initialized with a default value of `null` and linked to the `CommandMenuPageComponentInstanceContext`.

This file defines a React component, `CustomSlashMenuListItem`, which renders an individual item within a slash menu. It integrates with a selectable list system to manage selection state and handles user interactions for activating the suggested item.

This file defines a custom React component, `CustomSlashMenu`, which provides a dynamic slash command menu for a rich text editor. It handles the menu's positioning, animations, item rendering, and selection logic based on the current editor context.

This file defines a React component that manages the dropdown focus and state for the block editor's slash command menu. It listens for updates to the editor's suggestion menu to open or close the slash menu and adjust dropdown focus accordingly.
This file defines a React component that displays a warning message when AI API keys are not configured, prompting the user to set them and providing a link to relevant documentation.
This file defines a React component, AIChatStandaloneError, which renders an AI chat error message in a standalone format, complete with an AI avatar and error details.

This file defines a React component (`AIChatThreadsListEffect`) that manages UI focus state for an AI chat threads list. It registers the component within a global focus stack on mount and de-registers it on unmount, identifying it as a side panel.
This file defines the `AIChatEmptyState` React component, which renders the UI for an empty AI chat interface, prompting the user to start a new conversation.
This React component displays an error message for AI chat interactions, including an error icon, a customizable message, and a retry button to re-attempt the AI response.
This file defines a React component named `ShimmeringText` that applies a shimmering, animated gradient effect to its child text content using styled-components.

This React component displays AI reasoning or thought process summaries. It conditionally renders either a 'thinking' state with shimmering text or a toggleable, expandable display of the reasoning content when the AI has finished processing.

This file provides a React component that renders specific AI chat error messages based on the type of error encountered, such as API key issues or exhausted credits, or a generic error message otherwise.
This file defines a React component that displays a list of AI chat threads, grouped by date, and provides functionality to create new chat threads.

This file defines the `AIChatBanner` React component, a reusable UI element for displaying informational or warning messages within an AI chat interface. It supports different visual variants, custom messages, optional action buttons, and tooltips.

This file provides a lazy-loaded Markdown renderer component that parses and renders Markdown text, automatically converting specific record references into interactive links. It also includes custom styling for tables and paragraphs, and displays a loading skeleton during asynchronous loading.
This file defines the `AIChatTab` React component, which provides the user interface for an AI chat module, including displaying messages, handling user input, file uploads, and managing chat state.

This file defines the `TerminalOutput` React component, which displays terminal-like output including `stdout` and `stderr` in a tabbed interface, with options to copy the content and indicate if a process is running.

This file defines a React component responsible for rendering diverse message parts from an AI assistant in a chat interface. It dynamically displays reasoning, text, code execution, data routing, and tool-specific UI elements, including streaming and loading indicators.

This file defines a React component, `CodeExecutionDisplay`, that visualizes the results of a code execution. It displays the executed code, its terminal output (stdout/stderr), execution status (running, success, or error), and any generated files with preview capabilities.

This file defines the `ToolStepRenderer` React component, which visualizes a single step of an AI tool's execution within a UI, displaying its input, output, errors, and status, with special handling for code interpreter tools and expandable JSON views.
This file defines a React component for displaying a linked record with its name and an avatar. It also includes utilities for parsing specific record reference strings from text.

This file defines the `AIChatThreadGroup` component, which renders a grouped list of AI chat threads. It allows users to select a thread, which then updates the current chat state and displays usage details, opening the corresponding AI chat page.

This file defines the `AIChatMessage` React component, which is responsible for rendering a single message within an AI chat interface. It handles displaying message content, avatars, file attachments, errors, and metadata like timestamps, adapting its presentation based on whether the message is from a user or an AI assistant.

This file defines a React component, `ContextUsageProgressRing`, that displays a circular progress ring to visualize a given percentage of context usage. The color of the progress ring dynamically changes based on the usage level (e.g., red for high usage, blue for low usage).

This file provides a React component, `AIChatSkeletonLoader`, which displays a skeleton loading animation for an AI chat interface. It shows multiple placeholder message bubbles while content is being fetched.
This React component provides a button and hotkey functionality (Enter key) to send messages in an AI chat interface. It manages message sending based on input availability and loading state.

This React component displays the current AI chat context token usage as a button, showing a percentage and progress ring. On hover, it reveals a detailed breakdown of input/output tokens, total tokens, context window limit, and associated credits.

This file contains Storybook stories for the `AIChatMessage` component, demonstrating its various states and message types in an AI conversation context, including user messages, assistant text responses, streaming, and code execution (running, completed, and with errors).

This Storybook file defines various stories and test cases for the `CodeExecutionDisplay` React component, demonstrating its different states like running, success, error, and handling of output files.

Defines Storybook stories and automated tests for the `TerminalOutput` UI component, showcasing its rendering and interaction with different types of standard and error output, and various running states.
This file defines a constant `AI_CHAT_INPUT_ID` which serves as a unique identifier for an AI chat input element within the application.
This file defines a constant, `AI_CHAT_SCROLL_WRAPPER_ID`, which provides a unique identifier for the scrollable wrapper element within the AI chat interface.
This file defines a Recoil atom that tracks whether a new AI chat thread is currently in the process of being created.
Defines a Recoil atom to store the ID of the currently active AI chat thread. This state manages which AI chat thread is in focus within the application.
A React hook that manages file uploads for an AI chat feature, including handling file selection, sending files to the server, and managing upload states and errors.

This file defines a React hook `useGetBrowsingContext` that consolidates various application states to determine and return the current 'browsing context' for AI features, such as identifying if the user is on a record page or a list view with applied filters.

This directory is responsible for defining and managing application-wide state or data contexts specifically related to AI functionalities within the 'twenty-front' frontend application. It likely utilizes context providers to make AI-related data or services accessible throughout relevant components.

This file defines the `BrowsingContext` type, a discriminated union that describes the current state of a user's interaction with records or lists of records within an application. It specifies whether the user is on a single record page or a filtered list view.
Provides a utility function to check if a given error object is an AI chat error of a specific type by extracting and comparing its error code.
Provides a utility function to determine and return an appropriate icon component for a given tool name based on predefined keyword mappings.
This file provides utility functions, specifically type guards, to safely extract an error code from different structures of error objects, including nested and deeply nested formats.
This file provides a utility function to group AI chat threads by their creation date, categorizing them into 'today', 'yesterday', and 'older' for easier display or processing.
This file provides a utility function to map different AI agent response field types (e.g., string, number, boolean) to specific icon names for UI display.
Provides utility functions to generate user-friendly display messages for AI tool actions, especially for web search operations, indicating whether the search is ongoing or completed.

This file contains a utility function that transforms an array of database-centric `AgentMessage` objects into an array of UI-specific `ExtendedUIMessage` objects, suitable for display in the frontend.

This file defines a utility function that converts an 'AgentMessagePart' (likely from a database or backend) into an 'ExtendedUIMessagePart' suitable for display in the user interface, handling various message part types such as text, reasoning, files, and tool outputs.
This file contains unit tests for the `groupThreadsByDate` utility function, ensuring it correctly categorizes AI chat threads into 'today', 'yesterday', and 'older' based on their creation date.
This file contains unit tests for the `getFieldIcon` utility function, verifying its behavior for different field types including supported, unsupported, and edge cases.

This file contains unit tests for the `isAIChatErrorOfType` utility function. It verifies that the function correctly identifies whether a given error object has a specific AI chat error code, handling various matching and non-matching scenarios.

This file exports a GraphQL query named `GET_CHAT_THREADS` which is used to fetch a list of chat threads, including their ID, title, token and credit usage, and timestamps, likely for display in the AI module of the frontend application.
Defines the `ExtendedUIMessage` type, which extends a standard UI message to include AI-specific metadata such as usage statistics (tokens, credits) and model details (context window).
Defines the `ExtendedUIMessagePart` type, which specializes the `UIMessagePart` from the `ai` library by incorporating application-specific `DataMessagePart` and `UITools`.
This file defines a constant `DEFAULT_FAST_MODEL` which serves as an identifier for a default fast AI model within the application.
This file defines the `DEFAULT_SMART_MODEL` constant, which specifies the default identifier or name for a smart model within the AI module.

This file contains unit tests for the `isApiKeyNotConfiguredError` utility function. It verifies that the function correctly identifies errors specifically indicating a missing or unconfigured API key.
This TypeORM migration updates the default value for the 'modelId' column in the 'core.agent' table to 'default-smart-model' and provides a rollback to 'auto'.
This NestJS module centralizes the management and provision of AI models and related services, making them globally available throughout the application.

This file defines constants, types, and interfaces for various AI models, including their providers, specific model IDs, supported file types, and configuration details like cost, context window, and capabilities.

This file defines a constant array, `OPENAI_MODELS`, which lists configuration details for various OpenAI AI models, including active and deprecated versions, their costs, context windows, and capabilities.

This file defines a constant array, `XAI_MODELS`, which contains configurations for various AI models provided by XAI, including details like model IDs, labels, descriptions, costs, context windows, and native capabilities.
This file defines configuration constants for AI telemetry, specifying whether telemetry is enabled and if inputs and outputs should be recorded.
This file aggregates and exports a comprehensive list of all supported AI models from various providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, XAI). It also re-exports related types and default model identifiers.

This file defines and exports an array of configuration objects for various Anthropic AI models, including active and deprecated versions, with details such as model ID, cost, context window, and capabilities.

This file contains unit tests for the `AI_MODELS` constant, ensuring the integrity and structure of AI model definitions, and for the `AiModelRegistryService`, verifying its functionality in retrieving and managing AI model configurations.

This service provides an interface for interacting with AI language models. It handles retrieving specific or default AI models from a registry and offers a method to stream text responses from these models.

This service registers and manages available AI models from various providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, XAI, and OpenAI-compatible services) based on configured API keys. It provides methods to retrieve, resolve, and configure AI models for use within the application's AI agents.
This file re-exports core AI-related type definitions, including schemas for agent responses and model configurations, centralizing access to these types within the shared package.

This file defines the `ModelConfiguration` TypeScript type, which specifies optional settings for AI model features such as web and Twitter search, including their enablement status and configuration parameters.

This file defines the available output field types (text, number, boolean) for AI agent responses, including their display labels and associated UI icons. It also exports an interface for defining an output schema field.
This file provides React hooks to retrieve and format AI model options for UI selection components and to get the display label for a given AI model ID.

This file defines a React hook, `useGetToolIndex`, that fetches a list of AI tools and their metadata from a GraphQL API. It provides the tool index data, loading status, and any errors for use in React components.
This file defines a GraphQL fragment (`SKILL_FRAGMENT`) for the `Skill` type, specifying a standard set of fields to be included when querying skill-related data.
This file defines a GraphQL query named 'GET_TOOL_INDEX' that is used to retrieve an index of AI tools, including their names, descriptions, categories, object names, and input schemas.
Defines a GraphQL query named `FindOneSkill` to fetch a single skill by its unique ID, utilizing a shared skill fragment for consistent data structure.
This file defines a GraphQL query named `FindManySkills` that retrieves a list of skills, utilizing a reusable skill fragment for the data fields.
This file defines a GraphQL mutation named `CREATE_SKILL` for creating a new AI skill. It uses `SKILL_FRAGMENT` to specify the fields to be returned after the skill is created.
This file defines a GraphQL mutation named `ACTIVATE_SKILL` used to activate a skill, referencing a `SKILL_FRAGMENT` for its return type.
Defines a GraphQL mutation to deactivate a skill by its ID, leveraging a shared skill fragment for the returned data structure.
This file defines the `UPDATE_SKILL` GraphQL mutation, used for updating an AI skill. It utilizes the `SKILL_FRAGMENT` to ensure consistent data fields are returned after the update operation.
This file defines the GraphQL mutation `DELETE_SKILL`, used to remove an AI skill by its unique identifier and return the fields of the deleted skill.
Defines a GraphQL mutation named `RUN_EVALUATION_INPUT` for running an evaluation using a specified input string against a given AI agent within a frontend application.

This file defines and initializes a client-side state variable (`aiModelsState`) for storing an array of AI model configurations. It is used to manage the available AI models within the frontend application.

This file defines a React component for managing AI skills in the application settings. It provides a form to create, view, edit, delete, activate, and deactivate AI skills, handling form state, validation, and GraphQL mutations.
This file defines the main AI settings page component, which uses tabs to navigate and display different AI-related configurations such as skills, tools, and general AI router settings.
Defines the metadata and configuration for a table displaying AI skills in the settings interface, including field labels, types, and initial sort order.

This file defines constants for the AI settings page, specifically identifying the component instance and the various tabs (Skills, Tools, Settings) available within that section of the frontend application.

This file defines a React component that renders a dropdown menu for managing inactive AI skills within the settings. It provides options to activate an inactive skill and, if the skill is custom, an option to delete it.

This file defines the `SettingsAIMCP` component, which allows users to generate and copy configuration for connecting AI MCP clients to access workspace data, offering different schemas (core and metadata).
This file defines a React component `SettingsSkillTableRow` which renders a single row in a settings table, displaying an AI skill's icon, name, type, and an optional action.

This component renders a settings page that displays and manages AI tools. It presents two sections: custom user-defined tools (logic functions) which can be created and searched, and built-in system tools which can also be searched.

This file defines a React component that renders a table row for a system tool. It displays basic information about the tool and allows users to expand the row to view its description and input schema in a JSON tree format.

This file defines a React component, `SettingsToolTableRow`, which renders a single row in a table. It displays information about an AI 'tool' (a LogicFunction), including its name, type, and an optional action.
This component renders a sortable and searchable table for managing AI skills within the application's settings, allowing users to view, activate, delete, and add new skills.

This directory contains custom React hooks specifically designed to manage state, side effects, and provide reusable logic for the AI-related settings pages within the frontend application. It centralizes functionalities pertinent to the user's AI configuration and interactions.

This directory contains validation schemas specifically for AI-related settings pages within the frontend package. These schemas are used to define and enforce the structure and rules for data input or configuration related to artificial intelligence features.
This directory is designated for housing reusable UI components. These components are specifically designed for forms related to AI settings within the application's settings pages.

This directory serves as a configuration space for the Cursor AI editor within the 'twenty' project. It is intended to house custom rules, settings, or AI assistance configurations tailored for this specific repository. Currently, it is empty, suggesting no custom rules have been defined yet.

This file defines the `ToolInput` type by re-exporting the `input` property type from the `ToolUIPart` type in the `ai` library. It serves to provide a specific type definition for tool inputs within the application.
This global NestJS module consolidates and exports workflow-related tool services, primarily making `WORKFLOW_TOOL_SERVICE_TOKEN` available application-wide to prevent circular dependencies.
This migration adds `toolInputSchema` (JSONB) and `isTool` (boolean) columns to the `serverlessFunction` table, enabling the storage of input schemas for serverless functions that act as tools.

This file defines a factory that generates a set of AI tools for managing field metadata within a workspace. These tools enable querying, creating, updating, and deleting field metadata, utilizing Zod schemas for input validation and interacting with the `FieldMetadataService`.

This file defines a factory that generates AI-callable tools for managing and querying views within a workspace. It provides methods for reading (listing, getting query parameters) and writing (creating, updating, deleting) views.

This utility extracts specific file types intended for a code interpreter from AI UI messages, modifying the messages to include instructions for using these files. It identifies common document, spreadsheet, archive, and text file types.

This file exports a factory function that generates a set of AI tools for performing direct CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations on records. These tools are dynamically created based on object metadata and user permissions, encapsulating interactions with underlying record services.

This file contains unit tests for the `SearchService`. It verifies methods related to filtering and sorting search results, identifying metadata columns, and computing pagination cursors for the search functionality.

This module orchestrates the provision and registration of various 'tools' within the application, such as action, dashboard, database, and metadata tools. It consolidates different tool providers and makes them accessible via a ToolRegistryService.
This file defines interfaces and types for a `ToolProvider` within an AI system, including the context required for tool generation and retrieval, and an emitter for code execution updates.

This file defines the ActionToolProvider, responsible for providing a set of actionable tools (like HTTP requests, email, code interpreter, and help center search) to the AI engine. It dynamically generates available tools based on user permissions.

This file implements a ToolProvider that dynamically generates AI tools from configured logic functions within the application, allowing them to be executed as part of an AI workflow. It retrieves available logic functions marked as tools and converts them into a callable ToolSet.

This file defines the NativeModelToolProvider, which generates a set of AI tools based on the native model configured for a specific agent. It uses AI model registry and configuration services to resolve and retrieve these tools.
This file defines the ViewToolProvider, which dynamically generates 'view' related tools (read and optionally write) for the AI assistant based on the user's permissions within a given workspace.

This file defines a `ToolProvider` that generates AI tools for interacting with database records. It dynamically creates CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) tools for each database object, respecting user permissions and role configurations.

This file serves as an index for various core tools within the system, specifically exporting components related to loading other tools and skills. It consolidates exports from `load-tools.tool` and `load-skill.tool`.

This file defines a tool for loading specialized skills or expertise by name, returning detailed instructions for various tasks like workflow building, data manipulation, or research. It provides the schema for input and output, and the logic to fetch and return skill content.

This file defines the `ToolRegistryService`, responsible for managing and providing access to various AI tools. It handles indexing, searching, and retrieving tools from multiple providers, and prepares their schemas for use, including error handling.

This NestJS module (`ToolModule`) consolidates and provides various specialized tools like `HttpTool` and `CodeInterpreterTool`, along with a `SecureHttpClientService`, for use within the application.
This file defines the `ToolInput` type, representing a generic key-value object used for input parameters to a tool within the application.

This file defines the core `Tool` type and `ToolExecutionContext` interface, which together specify the structure and execution context for an AI-driven tool within the application, including its description, input schema, and execution logic.
Defines the `ToolContext` type, which provides contextual information for tools within the server's engine. It typically includes identifiers for the workspace, user, and role.
This file defines the `SecureAdapterDependencies` type, which specifies the necessary dependencies (like DNS lookup and an HTTP adapter) for creating a secure Axios adapter.

This file provides utility functions to wrap and unwrap schemas for AI tool execution, specifically by adding or removing a 'loadingMessage' property. It supports both Zod schemas and generic JSON schemas to include a status message for the user during execution.
Defines the Zod schema for the input of a code interpreter tool, specifying required Python code and optional files to be made available in the execution environment.

This file defines the `CodeInterpreterTool` class, which enables the execution of Python code in a sandboxed environment, handling input file downloads, code execution, and output file management for data analysis and other tasks.

This file defines the TypeScript types for input to a code interpreter tool. It specifies the structure for the code string to be executed and an optional array of file inputs, each with a filename and URL.
This file defines the Zod schema for the input of the `search-help-center-tool`, specifically for the search query to find relevant help articles.

This file defines a NestJS tool responsible for searching the Twenty documentation and help center. It makes API calls to retrieve information based on a user query, using either a configured Mintlify API or a default search endpoint.
This file defines the TypeScript type for the input parameters of the 'send email' tool. It infers this type directly from the `SendEmailInputZodSchema`.
This service manages the execution and listing of AI tools. It provides methods to handle tool calls by executing specified tools and to list available tools, wrapping responses in a JSON-RPC format.
This file provides a utility function to check if a given error specifically indicates that an AI API key has not been configured, using predefined AI chat error codes.

Defines and exports specific error codes for AI chat functionalities, primarily related to billing and API key configuration issues. It serves as a utility for standardizing AI-related error handling.

This file contains unit tests for the `extractErrorCode` utility function, ensuring it correctly extracts error codes from various error object structures, including nested ones, and handles invalid inputs gracefully.

This file defines a GraphQL query named `GET_CHAT_MESSAGES` which retrieves all chat messages and their detailed parts for a specified chat thread ID. It outlines the data structure for chat messages, including content, role, timestamps, and various part types like text, tool calls, and sources.
This file defines the GraphQL mutation `CREATE_CHAT_THREAD`. This mutation is used to create a new chat thread, returning its ID, title, creation timestamp, and update timestamp.

This NestJS module provides the core functionality for AI chat, managing chat threads, agent interactions, and tool utilization. It orchestrates services for chat execution, streaming, and title generation, integrating with various other modules for permissions, billing, file handling, and workspace management.
This file defines constant system prompts for the AI chat feature in Twenty CRM, guiding the AI's core behavior, tool usage strategy, and response formatting.

This directory is responsible for defining the data models or entities used specifically within the AI chat functionalities of the server engine's metadata modules. It likely contains schemas or definitions for objects like messages, conversations, or participants relevant to AI-driven chat interactions.

This directory contains Data Transfer Objects (DTOs) specifically designed for the AI chat module within the server's engine. These DTOs define the structured data formats used for communication and data exchange related to AI chat functionalities.

This directory contains the controllers for managing API requests related to AI chat functionalities within the server's metadata processing engine. It defines the endpoints and logic for interacting with the AI chat system.
This service orchestrates the execution of AI chat sessions, managing AI models, dynamic tool loading, skill integration, context building, and streaming AI responses for an AI agent.

This directory is designated to contain resolver functions for AI chat functionalities within the server's metadata engine. These resolvers would be responsible for fetching and manipulating data related to AI-powered chat features.

This service handles AI metadata-related JSON-RPC requests, including checking AI feature enablement, initializing capabilities, listing and executing AI tools, and managing prompts and resources for the Model Control Plane (MCP).

This service implements the Model Communication Protocol (MCP), processing JSON-RPC requests to manage and execute AI-related tools within a workspace, while handling authentication, authorization, and feature flag validation.

This file contains unit tests for the `McpProtocolService`, which handles the Multi-Client Protocol (MCP) interactions, including AI feature checks, role management, tool execution, and initialization within the application's engine.

This file contains integration tests for the Master Control Program (MCP) controller, verifying its JSON-RPC API endpoints. It tests various methods such as ping, initialize, tools listing and calling, and validates responses and error handling.

This file serves as a central re-export point for various AI-related type definitions, including agent responses, code execution states, chat usage metadata, and UI message structures. It aggregates type exports from several sub-modules within the `ai` directory.
This file defines TypeScript types for data messages, specifically detailing the structure for AI agent routing status and code execution results, including debugging information, state, and outputs.
This script uses pypdf to check if a given PDF file contains fillable form fields. It's intended to be run by an AI (Claude) to determine PDF interactivity.
This script fills specified form fields in a PDF document using values provided in a JSON file, performing validation and handling a pypdf bug related to selection list fields.
This script converts each page of a given PDF file into a separate PNG image, saving them to a specified output directory. It also includes optional scaling to limit image dimensions.

This script validates bounding boxes from a `fields.json` file generated by an AI (Claude) for PDF analysis, ensuring no overlaps between form field elements and that entry box heights are sufficient for their text content.

This script fills a PDF form by adding text annotations to specific locations, using data provided in a JSON file. It converts bounding box coordinates from an image's reference system to the PDF's coordinate system to place text accurately.

This file contains unit tests for the `check_bounding_boxes` module, verifying its ability to detect issues such as overlapping bounding boxes, inadequate entry box heights, and other structural problems in PDF form field configurations.

This script generates a 'validation' image by drawing bounding boxes (red for entry, blue for label) from a specified JSON file onto an input image for a given page number. It visualizes the bounding box information used for text annotations in PDFs, aiding in the validation of Claude's annotation placement.
This script extracts detailed information about fillable form fields from a PDF document, including their type, location, and options, and outputs this data as a JSON file.

This directory is designated for Spanish language user guide documentation specifically detailing the AI capabilities of the 'twenty' project. It outlines how AI features function within the application for users consuming content in Spanish.

This directory contains Chinese language 'how-to' guides specifically for AI-related features within the `twenty-docs` user guide. Its purpose is to provide practical, step-by-step instructions for users on utilizing the AI functionalities.

This directory is part of the Chinese localized user guide for the 'twenty' application, specifically detailing how users can obtain further assistance or support. It is expected to contain documentation on where to find additional help within the context of workflows and how-to guides.

This directory is designated to store Portuguese 'how-to' guides concerning Artificial Intelligence features within the 'twenty-docs' user documentation. It provides a structured location for practical, step-by-step instructions for users in the Portuguese language.

This directory is designated for documentation concerning the AI capabilities within the French user guide of the 'Twenty' software. It is expected to contain content detailing various AI-related features and functionalities for French-speaking users.

This directory is designated for hosting 'how-to' guides related to AI features, specifically for the French version of the user guide documentation within the 'twenty' project. Its purpose is to provide practical, step-by-step instructions for users interacting with AI functionalities.

This directory contains practical 'how-to' guides related to Artificial Intelligence, specifically for the Italian localization of the user guide within the 'twenty-docs' package. It serves to provide step-by-step instructions on AI-related topics for Italian-speaking users.

This directory contains Italian localized documentation for the user guide of the 'Twenty' project. Specifically, it details the various Artificial Intelligence (AI) capabilities offered by the software. Its role is to provide users with comprehensive information on these AI features in Italian.

This directory is part of the Italian user guide documentation for the 'twenty' package, specifically detailing how users can find additional help or support. It likely contains content or serves as a section for articles related to obtaining further assistance for workflows and how-to guides.

This directory contains practical how-to guides and step-by-step instructions for users interacting with AI-related features within the Twenty application. It is a part of the user guide documentation, focusing on task-oriented assistance.

This directory is part of the documentation package for the 'twenty' project, specifically within the user guide section. It is dedicated to detailing the Artificial Intelligence capabilities offered by the project. Its purpose is to house content explaining various AI features and functionalities.

This directory contains Turkish 'how-to' guides for AI features within the 'twenty' project's user documentation. It provides practical, step-by-step instructions for users engaging with AI functionalities.

This directory contains documentation outlining the specific AI capabilities available within the Twenty application. It is part of the Turkish localized user guide, detailing features related to artificial intelligence for users.

This directory is part of the 'twenty-docs' package, focusing on the Artificial Intelligence section of the user guide. It is intended to describe the AI features and functionalities available to users, specifically for the Romanian localization.
This file defines the configuration for an 'AI Meeting Transcript' application, detailing its display name, purpose, and required environment variables like API keys for Twenty and OpenAI services.

This application automatically processes meeting transcripts using AI (OpenAI) to extract summaries, key discussion points, action items, and commitments. It then creates formatted notes and tasks within the Twenty platform based on this analysis.

This file defines a serverless function that analyzes meeting transcripts using OpenAI to extract summaries, key points, action items, and commitments. It then integrates with the 'Twenty' platform to automatically create meeting notes and follow-up tasks based on this analysis.

This README details an AI-powered integration that automatically transforms meeting transcripts into structured notes, tasks, and assignments within Twenty CRM, leveraging webhooks for input and AI for analysis. It provides setup, configuration, usage instructions, and technical details for the feature.

This serverless function processes meeting transcripts, leveraging AI for analysis (e.g., summaries, action items) and integrating the results into the Twenty CRM by creating notes and linking them to relevant individuals.

Security & Compliance Auditing.description: Tracks and logs important system and user events, providing a comprehensive audit trail to ensure security and meet compliance requirements. This module monitors data changes and administrative actions.

files.description: This file provides a React hook `useEventTracker` for sending analytics events via a GraphQL mutation. It also includes utility functions to manage a session ID stored in a cookie, primarily for tracking pageviews.

This file contains unit tests for the `useEventTracker` custom React hook, verifying its functionality for tracking different types of analytics events (e.g., 'TRACK' and 'PAGEVIEW') by mocking GraphQL requests.
This file contains unit tests for the `makePageview` utility function, ensuring it correctly constructs pageview objects with default and provided properties for analytics tracking.
Defines data transfer objects (DTOs) for creating analytics events, including pageview and track events, used in a GraphQL API with validation rules.
This NestJS module defines the TelemetryModule, which provides and exports the TelemetryService. It is responsible for handling and sending telemetry data to the 'twenty-telemetry.com' API.

This service handles the creation and sending of telemetry events. It collects user and workspace information along with specific actions and payloads, dispatching them to a self-hosting endpoint if telemetry is enabled in the configuration.
This file defines a listener that processes user signup events, recording them in both the audit log and the telemetry system.

This file defines a React error boundary component (`AppErrorBoundary`) that catches JavaScript errors within its children, logs them to Sentry, and handles specific error types like Vite stale chunk lazy loading errors by reloading the page.

This file defines a React component, `AppFullScreenErrorFallback`, which provides a full-screen display for application errors. It serves as a visual fallback for error boundaries, presenting error details and a reset option.

This component registers a global event listener for unhandled promise rejections, displaying user-friendly error notifications (snack bars) and reporting these errors to Sentry for monitoring, while handling specific error types like ApolloErrors and AbortErrors.
Initializes Sentry for error tracking and performance monitoring within the application, dynamically setting up its configuration and identifying the current user based on application state.

This file defines the `AppRootErrorFallback` React component, which serves as a visual fallback UI for application-level errors. It displays an error message, an illustration, and a reload button to reset the error boundary.

This file defines a React component, `AppPageErrorFallback`, which serves as a page-level error boundary fallback. It displays application errors within a standard page layout, utilizing `AppErrorDisplay` to render the error details and providing options to reset the error boundary.

This component resets the React error boundary whenever the application's route (location) changes, ensuring that navigation away from an error state clears the error boundary. It helps in recovering from errors during routing transitions.

This file defines custom exception codes and a dedicated `AuditException` class for handling errors specifically related to auditing within the application, providing structured error handling with user-friendly messages.

This file defines a NestJS exception filter responsible for catching and handling `AuditException`s. It specifically translates `INVALID_TYPE` and `INVALID_INPUT` audit exceptions into `UserInputError`s for consistent error reporting.
This service provides a mechanism for capturing and handling exceptions within the application by delegating the actual exception processing to an injected driver.

This file defines a configurable NestJS module builder for the `ExceptionHandlerModule`. It sets up the necessary components (class, tokens, types) to allow the module to be dynamically configured and initialized, typically via a `forRoot` method.
This NestJS module provides a global exception handling mechanism, allowing configuration of either a console-based or Sentry-based driver for logging and reporting exceptions.

This file defines a factory function that dynamically configures the exception handling module. It selects and initializes the appropriate exception handler (e.g., console or Sentry) based on application configuration.
This file defines a console driver for the exception handler module. It implements the `ExceptionHandlerDriverInterface` to capture and log exceptions to the console.

This file implements a Sentry driver for the application's exception handling system, responsible for capturing and reporting exceptions to Sentry with detailed context and specific handling for various exception types.
This file provides a mock implementation of the `ExceptionHandlerDriverInterface`. It is used for testing purposes, returning a generic 'mocked-exception-id' for any captured exceptions.
This file defines the interfaces and types for configuring an exception handling module, including options for different drivers like Sentry and Console.
This file acts as a barrel file, re-exporting all interfaces related to the exception handler and its drivers within the core engine module.

This file defines the `ExceptionHandlerUser` interface, specifying the structure for basic user information (ID, email, name) that might be associated with an exception for logging or reporting purposes.

This file defines the `ExceptionHandlerOptions` interface, specifying the structure for configuration and contextual data passed to an exception handler, including details about the GraphQL operation, user, workspace, and additional arbitrary data.
This file defines the `ExceptionHandlerDriverInterface`, which outlines the contract for classes responsible for capturing and processing exceptions within the application.

This file defines an Envelop plugin named `useSentryTracing` that integrates Sentry tracing into GraphQL operations. It captures details like the operation name, type, user information, and the GraphQL document for Sentry monitoring.
This file contains unit tests for the `ExceptionHandlerService`, ensuring it can be properly instantiated and is defined within the NestJS testing environment.

This component displays detailed information for a background job (`QueueJob`) within an expandable panel, including its data, return values, logs, and any error messages or stack traces. It is used in the admin settings for health status.
This file defines a React component that displays a table summarizing key health-related counters for account synchronization jobs within the application's admin panel.
This file defines a React component for a confirmation modal used in the admin panel's health status section. It prompts the user to confirm the retry operation for one or more jobs.
Defines a GraphQL query to fetch jobs from a specific queue, allowing filtering by state and pagination, primarily used for monitoring queue health in an admin panel.

This module provides monitoring functionalities for messaging channels, including cron jobs and commands to track their synchronization status. It integrates common messaging features and auditing capabilities.
This service provides an interface for managing and monitoring message queue jobs within an administrative panel. It allows fetching, retrying, and deleting jobs from BullMQ queues.

This service provides an interface for interacting with OpenTelemetry metrics, including creating counters and gauges. It also integrates with a metrics cache for persistent storage and retrieval of event-based counts.
Defines an enumeration of keys used for tracking various system metrics, including job statuses, API operations, workflow runs, and other important events within the application.

This file defines a constant value for the metrics failure rate threshold. This threshold is likely used within the server's health monitoring system to identify when a metrics failure rate is considered unacceptable.
This utility manages and tracks the health state of a system component, storing details, a timestamp, and providing the age of the last known state.
This file defines a health indicator for background workers and their associated BullMQ queues, providing detailed metrics like job counts and failure rates to determine their operational status.
This NestJS module orchestrates the trash cleanup process, providing services, jobs, and cron commands to periodically remove trashed entities, including workspace-related data.

This component displays an 'actor' (e.g., user, system, integration) with an avatar chip, dynamically selecting an icon based on the actor's source and context. It provides a visual representation for various entities involved in actions or records.
This file defines a `CommandLogger` service responsible for creating log directories and writing JSON log data to files, organized by class name, within a `logs` directory.

This file defines an array of mock audit events (fixtures) used for seeding a ClickHouse database, primarily for testing or development purposes. It includes various object and workspace-related tracking events.
This file defines a custom `CommandLogger` class that wraps NestJS's `Logger`, adding a `verbose` logging level which can be toggled on or off.

This README documents the Analytics Module, detailing how to track various events (workspace, object, pageview) within the Twenty application and providing instructions for adding new custom events to the system.

This file defines a NestJS GraphQL resolver for audit-related operations, handling mutations for tracking analytics, pageviews, and object events. It integrates with an audit service to record various user and system activities.

This file contains unit tests for the `AuditResolver`, ensuring its methods for tracking analytics (pageviews, custom events) and creating object-related audit events function correctly and handle various inputs, including error conditions.
This NestJS module encapsulates the application's auditing functionality, integrating with ClickHouse for data storage and providing an `AuditService` for managing audit events.
This file defines common TypeScript type aliases for audit properties and identifiers used within the twenty-server package, such as 'timestamp', 'version', 'workspaceId', and 'userId'.
This file defines and aggregates all trackable audit event types, including their names and corresponding data structures, used across the system for consistent event tracking and logging.

This file provides utility functions for creating formatted analytics and audit events. It includes functions to generate pageview events and generic track events, incorporating common properties and schema validation.
Defines a base Zod schema (`baseEventSchema`) for common properties found in various events, such as timestamp, user ID, workspace ID, and version.

This file defines the Zod schema for a 'pageview' event, specifying its structure and properties for tracking user page interactions. It includes details like href, locale, and user agent, extending a base event schema.
This file defines a generic schema for 'track' audit events and provides utilities to register and manage specific event schemas within an audit system.
Defines and registers the schema for a 'User Signup' audit event, ensuring data consistency for user registration tracking within the application.
Defines and registers the 'Logic Function Executed' audit event, including its schema for tracking details like duration, status, and function identifiers within a workspace.
This file defines and registers the 'Custom Domain Activated' audit event. It specifies the event's schema using Zod and integrates it into the application's event tracking system.

This file defines the `Custom Domain Deactivated` event, including its Zod schema, and registers it within the audit event tracking system. It signifies when a custom domain has been deactivated for a workspace.

This file defines and registers a Zod schema for a 'Monitoring' event, specifying its expected properties for tracking audit-related activities. It allows for consistent data capture for monitoring events within the system.
This file defines the schema and registers the 'Webhook Response' event for tracking, including details like status, success, URL, and any errors, within an audit or event logging system.

This file defines and registers a Zod schema for a 'Workspace Entity Created' audit event, specifying its structure and properties. It enables the system to track and validate the creation of entities within a workspace.

This NestJS module orchestrates audit-related background jobs. It specifically provides the logic for creating audit logs from internal system events, leveraging both the main audit functionality and a timeline activity module.
This file defines a message queue processor that listens for internal object record events (like create, update, delete) and generates corresponding audit log entries based on the event type.

This file defines the `Analytics` Data Transfer Object (DTO) for GraphQL responses within the audit core module. It specifies a single boolean field, `success`, to indicate whether a query or operation was successfully dispatched.

This file contains unit tests for the `AuditService`, specifically focusing on its `createContext` method and the functionality of inserting various audit events like workspace, pageview, and object events.
This service manages and dispatches various audit events (workspace events, object events, and pageviews) to ClickHouse, conditionally based on the ClickHouse configuration.
This file acts as an aggregation point, re-exporting all interfaces defined in `logger.interface.ts` to provide a single entry for logger-related types.

This pre-query hook automatically injects the 'updatedBy' field, derived from the authenticated actor's context, into updateOne operations before they are processed. It ensures that the 'updatedBy' information is consistently set for records being updated.
This file defines a pre-query hook that automatically injects the 'updatedBy' field into the data payload for 'updateMany' operations, using the actor information from the authentication context.
This file defines a pre-query hook that automatically injects the 'created by' actor information into the data payload for `createOne` operations, using the authenticated user's context.

This file defines a pre-query hook that automatically injects 'created by' actor information into the records for any 'createMany' operation before it is executed, ensuring proper attribution for newly created data.

This utility formats individual ORM-generated database events (create, update, delete, restore, destroy, upsert) into a standardized batch event structure. It processes record changes based on the action and generates appropriate event objects, excluding timeline activity events.

This utility function converts or adapts different types of Workspace query builders (e.g., update, delete, insert) into a WorkspaceSelectQueryBuilder. It is used to construct a SELECT query based on the context, conditions, and parameters of an existing query builder, likely for event logging or auditing.

This file contains unit tests for the `formatTwentyOrmEventToDatabaseBatchEvent` utility function. It verifies that the utility correctly transforms TwentyORM update events into database batch events, including handling data consistency and mapping 'before' and 'after' states for records.

This file defines a NestJS listener that subscribes to various database entity events (create, update, delete, etc.). It dispatches these events to different message queues for processing, including triggering webhooks, database event triggers, audit log creation, and timeline activity updates.

This file provides a utility to create mock audit context objects for testing purposes. It generates mock functions (using `jest.fn()`) for tracking various events like workspace, object, and pageview events, allowing tests to control and inspect their behavior without real audit system integration.

This integration test verifies that analytics events sent via the GraphQL API are correctly registered and stored in the ClickHouse database's `workspaceEvent` table. It simulates an event, sends it to the server, and then queries ClickHouse to confirm its persistence and accuracy.

This file serves as an index for the database event module, re-exporting various types and classes related to database record operations such as creation, updates, deletions, and their associated payloads or differences.
Defines an enum `EventLogTable` which specifies the different categories or tables used for logging events within the application, such as workspace events, pageviews, and object events.
This NestJS module orchestrates the validation logic for blocklist-related entities. It imports necessary repositories and exposes a validation service for use within the application.

This service handles the validation logic for blocklist items, ensuring that new or updated entries conform to a specified schema (email or domain format) and maintain uniqueness within a user's blocklist for a given workspace.
This file defines a NestJS Commander question set for confirming sensitive operations, specifically database deletion, prompting the user with a warning and suggesting a dry run option.
This file defines a constant string used to mask sensitive application variable values, typically for display or logging purposes to prevent direct exposure.
Validates tracked changes in Word documents, specifically ensuring that any modifications authored by 'Claude' are correctly redlined (i.e., appear as insertions or deletions).
Utility function to remove the initial file folder segment from a given file path, ensuring the segment is a valid 'FileFolder' type.

This utility file defines a function to validate if the root folder of a given file path is an allowed folder, throwing an error if it's not. It ensures that file operations are restricted to predefined directories.

This utility file provides a function to sanitize file content, specifically targeting SVG files using DOMPurify to mitigate potential XSS vulnerabilities. For non-SVG files, it returns the content unchanged.
This file defines a NestJS module for secret encryption. It encapsulates and exports the SecretEncryptionService to be consumed by other modules within the application.

This file defines the `ThrottlerModule` for a NestJS application. It encapsulates and exports the `ThrottlerService`, making it available for dependency injection and use across other modules to manage rate limiting.

This file contains unit tests for the `CastToLogLevelArray` decorator, ensuring it correctly transforms string representations of log levels (single or comma-separated) into an array of valid log levels, or `undefined` for invalid inputs.

This file contains unit tests for the `configVariableMaskSensitiveData` utility, verifying its functionality for various masking strategies like `LAST_N_CHARS` and `HIDE_PASSWORD`, as well as handling edge cases.

This file provides a GraphQL Yoga plugin to validate the complexity of incoming GraphQL queries. It analyzes queries for field count, nesting depth, and root resolver count to prevent overly complex requests.
